texts.shortText: Stout, white amphipod with broad limbs adapted for burrowing in sand. The head bears an unusual and distinctive pointed ‘hood’ that projects forward over the eyes, much like the peak of a cap. The first two pair of limbs bear small claws and in the third pair the last joint is expanded into a distinctive spade-like lobe edged by large spines to aid in digging. The basal joints of the last pair of limbs are greatly expanded and lobed.

Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
Burrows through sand on exposed sandy beaches, much like a mole.
Assumed to scavenge on detritus and any other food particles found between the sand grains.
As with all amphipods, the eggs are retained within a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of the female, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles prior to release.

The tapering peak-like hood extending over the front of the head immediately identifies this species as a member of the family Phoxocephalidae (phoxo=tapering, cephala = head). This is the only species in the genus, which is named after the author of this entry, but it can be confused with Basuto stimpsoni, which has similar habits and overall appearance, but lacks the spade-like foot on the third pair of legs.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 96).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 27).

Jarrett, NE & Bousfield, EL (1994). The Amphipod superfamily Phoxocephaloidea on the Pacific coast of north America. Family Phoxocephalidae. Part II. Subfamilies Pontharpiniidae, Parharpiniinae, Brolginae, Phoxocephalinae, and Harpiniinae. Amphipacifica, 1(2), 71-150.
